Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Determining Forms and Data Assimilation with Stochastic Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
Among the numerous factors that make accurate weather forecasting a challenge is initialization. The finite number of data collecting instruments distributed about the globe and atmosphere give only an incomplete description of the state of the weather at any instant. Yet there is a wealth of such data over an extended time period in the past, which when combined with certain mathematical models can provide a more complete description. The general procedure for this is called data assimilation. It provides more accurate starting values for computer simulations of the weather going into the future. This award funds research into a new method of data assimilation that is flexible enough to be combined with a variety of simulation techniques. The work will concern both the implementation of this method, and the effect of measurement errors in the data, which inevitably occur. The assimilation process leads to another mathematical model that can be used to cleanse the past data of such noise. In this second direction, the goal is not to obtain a higher resolution condition for starting a simulation for the future, but to reconstruct a highly resolved version over the time period of the original data. This has natural applications in voice and pattern recognition.

The research team will implement a recent data assimilation algorithm based on feedback control for several important physical systems. The approach can be applied with a variety of determining parameters, such as nodal values, and finite volume elements. The team will also carry out computations with a new determining form based on feedback control. The steady states of this ordinary differential equation are precisely the finite-dimensional projections of trajectories in the global attractor. The team will study both computationally and analytically the effects of stochastic perturbations in the data. In the case of the data assimilation algorithm, the plan is to quantify and control the effect of the noise on the highly resolved state to be used in a subsequent direct numerical simulation. In the case of the determining form, the idea is to use its evolutionary process to remove the noise from the data itself.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research from this project includes one negative result and four positive results.  The positive results appear in three published papers, two submitted papers and one in preparations.

1.  It was shown that blurred-in-time observational measurements do not pose a significant obstacle to data assimilation provided the blur is not too much and is compensated for using appropriate modifications to the assimilation algorithms.

2.  It was discovered that approximate inertial manifolds not not function well for interpolating observational data, possibly due to their non-linear nature.

3.  It was shown that dynamically-motivated spectral filtering in space is effective in theory and in practice in the context of a classical data assimilation algorithm for the case when the data interpolation is done by non-orthogonal linear operators.

4.  It was shown that the model error in a number of deterministic turbulence models is uncorrelated over long time intervals and grows at a sublinear rate reminiscent of a noise process which is white in time.  This helps to supports the derivation of variational data assimilation algorithms which, in fact, assume the model error can be modeled by such a noise process.

5.  It was shown that most pullback attractors in the sense of Baire category are continuous with respect to perturbations of the dynamics.  This implies that the set of possible outcomes for a data assimilation experiment do not change significantly when the dynamics are approximated.

This grant provided a good computer and GPU which was used to develop parallel software to perform data assimilation experiments.  The resulting software was run on the UNR Grid cluster and with the sponsorship of a co-PI on Big Red II at Indiana University.

This project impacted two graduate students at UNR and one postdoc.

1.  One graduate student was supported by this grant for two semesters.  During this time she defended her master's thesis, published a paper in a refereed journal and is now working on a Ph.D. in computer science.  Figure 1 is a graph from that paper which shows the expected difference between an approximating solution obtained by data assimilation and the exact solution over time.

2.  The second graduate student, while not directly supported by this grant, worked on research related to this project.  He recently defended his master's thesis on both theory and computational aspects of global attractors and is currently working toward a Ph.D. in applied mathematics.  Figure 2  is a graph from his thesis showing a non-recurrent part of the global attractor for the Kuramoto-Sivashinsky equations which govern combustion patterns in thin films.

3.  The postdoctoral student coauthored and submitted a paper based on research related to this project.  While no longer at UNR, collaboration is ongoing and she is currently working on an additional related paper.  Figure 3 is a graph from the paper under development which denotes weather forecasting stations by circles along with their corresponding domains of interpolation.
